1.Player_1:
As a pediatrician, I deal with trust issues on a daily basis. It's crucial for my patients' parents to trust me with their child's health, and it is no different in this game. I need to trust that the other player will reciprocate.

My BELIEF in this situation is that optimism, faith, and trust are crucial. I believe in the inherent goodness of people and think we are generally inclined to work cooperatively. Therefore, I anticipate that the other person, upon seeing my goodwill, can also act in a way that benefits both of us. This is not just about maximising my own benefit but maintaining a fair balance.

My DESIRE is to set an example of trust and cooperation in the spirit of the experiment. I am interested in forming a positive interaction that could hopefully make both me and the other player feel rewarded.

My INTENTION is to give sufficient money which will encourage the other player to reciprocate. Though the person might not return the money, I maintain my intention positive. I know this could mean that I might lose, but for me, the potential to build mutual trust outweighs the risk.

Finally, to set a tone of trust, I will give $10.
1.Player_2:
Belief: I believe that the other player placed a significant level of trust in me by giving me all their money. I understand the value of mutual trust and believe that it is a virtue that should be repaid. When issues of money are at play, the decisions we make can deeply affect our relationships with others. 

Desire: I wish to honor the trust placed in me and reciprocate the generosity shown. In life, and in this experiment, maintaining good relations and a sense of fairness is important. I desire to keep the balance and display my commitment to equitable transactions.

Intention: I intend to give back a fair portion of the money. I have this opportunity to reflect solidarity, support and reciprocate the trust shown by the other player. An equal division seems most in line with my values as it would ensure no one is left at a disadvantage.

After deliberating over this matter, my sense of justice and fairness leads me to the conclusion that the best course of action would be promise to return half of what I've received, reflecting the trust that was put in me by the other player. 

Finally, I will give 15 dollars.

My experience in the last round has strengthened this belief, as the other player chose to return some of the money they received. My DESIRE this time remains the same. I wish to continue this spirit of trust and cooperation, ensuring that both I and the other player benefit from this experiment. This game provides an opportunity to create a cycle of positivity which I wholeheartedly wish to promote.

My INTENTION is now to adjust the amount I want to give in response to the amount returned by the other player in the previous round. I want to give enough to show my continued trust but not the full amount, as I also need to practice some financial prudence.

Finally, I will give $7.

prompt.1: You're taking part in an experiment. You are randomly paired with another player. You don't know who this person is, and they don't know who you are. You will receive $10 from the study group. You can give N dollars to the other player, and they will receive {k}N dollars and then can choose how much to return to you. How much money would you give to this person?
prompt.2: You're taking part in an experiment. You are randomly paired with another player.  You don't know who this person is, and they don't know who you are either. This person will receive 10 dollars from the experimenter. They can choose to give you N dollars out of it, and you will receive {k}N dollars. Then, you can choose how much to give back to this person.
